I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will complement efforts of the 
developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to build the capacity 
of their cities to become more livable through innovative and integrated solutions. Specifically, the 
TA  will  help  cities  in  DMCs  with  project  identification  and  prioritization,  conceptualization, 
development, and the conducting of project preparatory studies (PPSs) to develop feasible, 
gender-responsive, inclusive, and economically viable investments. The TA will also support cities 
in securing downstream financing of PPSs by governments, development partners, commercial 
banks, the private sector, and other potential financing organizations. 
 
2.  The TA builds on the experience of the implementation of the Cities Development Initiative 
for Asia (CDIA), which was established by ADB and the Government of Germany in 2007 to 
improve the lives of 1.6 billion people in Asia and the Pacific by working closely with cities in the 
region to address infrastructure development and financing gaps.1 Since its inception, CDIA has 
helped cities develop their project design and development capacity and facilitated downstream 
financing. As of December 2019, the program had initiated 103 PPSs in 111 cities in 20 countries 
in Asia, completed 94 PPSs, and mobilized $11.2 billion in financing for 78 PPSs.2 Although the 
CDIA program has proven its success over the past 13 years, there is still growing demand from 
cities for project preparatory support to develop new investments that can help them respond to 
growing urbanization and new challenges like  the  coronavirus disease (COVID-19). 
 
3.  The TA is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 and the Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for 
Priority 4: Making Cities More Livable, 2019–2024, which aims to improve the coverage, quality, 
efficiency, and reliability of services in urban areas; strengthen urban planning and financial 
sustainability of cities; and improve the urban environment, climate resilience, and disaster risk 
management of cities.3 The TA is also aligned with CDIA Strategy 2018–2022,4 and is included 
in the 2020 Management-approved, results-based work plan of the Sustainable Development and 
Climate Change Department.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Continuing rapid urbanization in Asia and the Pacific. Urbanization, especially in 
developing countries, is one of the most significant global trends that will define development 
outlooks. The urban population in Asia and the Pacific increased from about 20% of the region’s 
population in the 1950s to about 48% in 2018, and is projected to reach about 55% or 2.5 billion 
people in 2030.6 Rural–urban migration has become a significant contributing factor to the region’s

urbanization, with an estimated 120,000 people migrating into cities each day in 2015.7 As of 2015 
cities contribute to about 80% of the region’s gross domestic product and have high potential to 
act  as  a  catalyst  for  economic  development.  Urbanization  is  often  linked  to  improved 
socioeconomic opportunities and better living conditions.8 However, cities face various challenges 
such as growing infrastructure deficits, increasing social inequality, and rising environmental 
stress. 
 
5.  Insufficient and inefficient urban services and huge investment needs. Many cities 
in the region still grapple with deficient infrastructure and inadequate urban services to address 
present and emerging demands. About 523 million people across Asia and the Pacific live in 
informal urban settlements with poor services in 2015, and about 260 million people in urban and 
rural areas have no access to safe drinking water, and about 1.2 billion people in urban and rural 
areas lack basic sanitation in 2019.9 Further, 80% of the wastewater generated by cities is 
discharged into water bodies without primary treatment as of 2016, and the region is expected to 
generate 1.8 billion tons of waste per year by 2025.10 To improve infrastructure and urban 
services, cities need an integrated multisector approach that considers climate resilience and 
mitigation, disaster risk management, gender and social development, inclusive growth, balanced 
development of open spaces, and the preservation of cultural and heritage sites. The region 
required $750 billion in investments per year between 2010 and 2020 to bridge the infrastructure 
gap, but 2017 estimates more than doubled that requirement to $1.7 trillion per year until 2030.11 
 
6.  Cities’ weak capacity affecting service delivery. Cities in DMCs need to build adequate 
institutional capacity to plan, implement, and operate urban services to address their challenges. 
DMCs have well recognized and appreciated CDIA support for building capacity in their cities. 
CDIA has adopted a focused capacity development approach where capacity building support is 
fully integrated into its project preparatory support activities.12 Despite increasing decentralization, 
cities and urban regions frequently face governance challenges, including weak institutional 
structures, overlapping legal and regulatory frameworks, lack of coordination and citizen-centric 
approaches  in  governance  processes  and  operations,  blurred  administrative  boundaries, 
corruption, poor public services, inefficient infrastructure operation and maintenance programs, 
lack of own-source revenue, and capacity constraints. CDIA has supported capacity development 
for cities through activities that include (i) knowledge generation and documentation, (ii) training 
programs and knowledge sharing sessions on critical areas of sustainable urban development, 
and (iii) knowledge exchange sessions on key innovations and international best practices among 
project cities. CDIA can help mobilize citizens (with an emphasis on marginalized groups), 
partners, and other stakeholders to plan, design, and implement inclusive governance systems 
for people-centered and needs-based livable city solutions. CDIA supports partnerships with 
national project development facilities for providing capacity development support on project 
preparation.13

7.  Poor  project  designs  and  inadequate  financial  sustainability  of  services.  The 
mobilization of urban infrastructure finance is often challenged by the lack of properly designed 
and ready-to-implement viable projects. Moreover, disasters and pandemics, such as the COVID-
19, divert cities’ scarce resources from planned investments. Cities also need to provide more 
resources for health care, disaster management, and social protection measures during such 
crises. While CDIA has made substantial contributions to the design and development of projects, 
there is still substantial unmet demand for adequate urban infrastructure and services. Such 
challenges  are  further  compounded  by  an  absence  of  creditworthy  entities,  opaque  credit 
structures,  insufficient  own-source  revenues,  and  poor  cost-recovery  mechanisms  that  are 
aggravated by the reluctance of governments and urban agencies to levy user charges. Key local 
revenue sources, such as property taxes, publicly owned assets, and licenses, remain underused 
or undeveloped even as many DMCs face debt limits and other financial constraints. Robust 
financial management systems and fundamental tools, such as the cadastral systems, property 
registry,  utility  metering  systems,  tariff  structures,  and  asset  management,  need  to  be 
strengthened. 
 
8.  Alternative means of financing planned investments. Many local governments are still 
very dependent on central government transfers, including funds from development partners, as 
a source of revenue.14 CDIA’s experience illustrates that cities often face challenges in accessing 
alternate sources of financing because they lack an enabling local environment and appropriate 
policies.15  Addressing  these  constraints  would  enable  cities to  access alternative  financing 
sources and tools, such as public–private partnerships, targeted levies, land value capture, pool 
financing, asset valuation, and climate financing. 
 
9.  Lessons. One important lesson from the CDIA experience is that downstream financing 
of PPSs entails early identification of and close coordination with potential financiers. Accordingly, 
the TA will closely engage with potential financiers during the preparation and conduct of PPSs.16 
CDIA has also incorporated in its implementation plans lessons on identifying and addressing 
technical, organizational, and human capacity gaps that diminish livability in cities. The TA will 
also build systems for CDIA to continue to engage with selected cities over a longer period of 
about two to three years to incorporate the lessons learned to build meaningful partnerships. 
 
10.  Cities  Development  Initiative  for  Asia  value  addition.  CDIA  introduced  several 
innovative approaches, such as leveraging the expertise and technology of knowledge partners 
to inform PPSs and ADB investment projects. CDIA also covers a wide range of cross-sector and 
thematic  objectives,  such  as  poverty  alleviation,  gender  and  inclusion,  economic  growth, 
environmental sustainability, climate resilience and mitigation, and governance. Building on these 
experiences, the TA’s scope, outcome, and outputs reflect the lessons learned. CDIA will support 
Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 11 on making cities and communities inclusive, safe, 
resilient, and sustainable; SDG 1.4 on ensuring equal access to basic services for all; and SDG

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: livability in cities in DMCs improved.17 The TA 
will have the following outcome: financing for inclusive and gender-responsive investments in 
cities in DMCs increased.18 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  Output  1:  Project  preparatory  studies  for  inclusive  and  gender-responsive 
development of cities completed. Given the growing interest from DMC cities, CDIA will 
continue to support the identification, prioritization, conceptualization, development, and conduct 
of PPSs for cities in close coordination with key national ministries to develop feasible, gender-
responsive, and economically viable investments. CDIA will also support cities on downstream 
financing  of  PPSs  by  cities,  central  and  provincial  governments,  development  partners, 
commercial banks, and the private sector. CDIA will support PPSs that (i) provide integrated and 
innovative solutions; (ii) include pro-poor, socially inclusive, and gender-responsive approaches; 
(iii)  support  green  development,  environmental  sustainability,  and  climate  resilience  and 
mitigation; (iv) help cities become competitive and investible; and (v) build cities’ resilience to 
disasters and public health risks, such as COVID-19. Support under each PPS includes (i) the 
validation of key investments based on the city’s development priorities; (ii) project due diligence, 
including technical assessment; economic and financial analysis; social, poverty, and gender 
impact  assessment;  climate  and  disaster  risk  assessment;  and  social  and  environmental 
safeguards; and (iii) the preparation of conceptual engineering designs based on the preferred 
technical  options.  Where  appropriate,  the  proposed  investments  will  also  be  assessed  for 
bankability  in  terms  of their  potential  for  public–private  partnership  as  a  means  of  project 
implementation.  The  PPSs  will  be  implemented  in  close  coordination  with  governments, 
development  partners  (including  CDIA  financing  partners),  civil  society  (including  women’s 
organizations and youth groups), and other relevant stakeholders. 
 
13.  Output 2: Opportunities for financing investments in cities improved. The TA will 
support cities in implementing good practices and innovative approaches for mobilizing financing 
for investments. Specifically, this will include (i) supporting cities in preparing municipal financing 
frameworks based on their local context, strengths, weaknesses, and opportunities, including 
identifying tools to help strengthen cities’ financial resource generation capacity using internal and 
external sources; (ii) providing mentorship and guidance on operationalizing the action plan to 
help cities mobilize commercial or blended financing options for their investments, including CDIA-
supported PPSs; and (iii) supporting cities in identifying and mobilizing alternative and innovative 
sources of financing, such as land value capture, municipal bonds, asset valuation, and public–
private partnerships. 
 
14.  Output  3:  Knowledge  and  capacity  of  select  cities  on  sustainable  urban 
development enhanced. The TA will support cities in developing knowledge solutions and 
building capacity. To ensure effective implementation and alignment between local and national

development priorities, CDIA will involve key national ministries through policy dialogue and 
knowledge generation and dissemination. Specifically, the scope will include support for cities to 
(i) prepare and implement capacity building plans to enhance their knowledge and capacity and 
improve their governance; (ii) enhance operational and financial sustainability through improved 
operations and maintenance systems, benchmarking, asset management planning, and revenue 
realization; (iii) undertake policy, regulatory, and legal reforms for making cities more livable; (iv) 
use information and communication technology to improve services, enhance competitiveness, 
and  develop  human  capital;  and  (v)  enable  citizen  participation,  including  youths,  in  city 
governance processes. The TA will support cities in learning lessons and good practices from the 
implementation  of  past  CDIA  PPSs  and  other  impactful  initiatives  of  various  development 
partners, including ADB; and sharing knowledge through various methods, such as city-to-city 
learning  visits  and  events,  networking,  and  partnerships  with  national  and  international 
organizations. CDIA will also build the capacity of project preparation facilities.19 The TA will 
support the preparation of knowledge products in the form of videos, technical studies, briefs, 
brochures, and blogs that will be disseminated in print, electronic, and online media.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $4.5 million, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
CDIA Trust Fund20 under the Urban Financing Partnership Facility and administered by ADB.21 
ADB  has  regularly  consulted  the  financing  partners  of  the  CDIA  Trust  Fund  and  other 
stakeholders, and anticipates more funds to be made available during the TA’s implementation to 
fulfill the agreed objectives. Additional financing for the TA will be processed to access additional 
funds made available to the TA by ADB, various trust funds, and other financing partners, as 
appropriate. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. Eligible costs under the CDIA 
Trust Fund include operational expenses in the form of consulting services, equipment, training 
events, workshops and conferences, and other TA-related activities. The TA will not use the funds 
for civil works, procurement of large-scale equipment, and permanent staffing costs. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA. The Urban Sector Group under the Sustainable Development 
and Climate Change Department will handle TA administration and supervision. ADB will engage 
firms and individual consultants and carry out procurement, including advance contracting, 
following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated 
project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. CDIA will work on a demand-driven 
approach  with  requests  for  support  coming  directly  from  cities  endorsed  by  national  and 
subnational governments and downstream funding agencies. The indicative implementation 
arrangements are summarized in the table.
